awd_titl_txt: EarthCube Data Capabilities: Argovis 2.0: A Next Generation Platform for co-located Oceanic and Atmospheric Data to Accelerate Climate Science Workflows
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop Argovis 2.0, a web application for binding co-located atmospheric and oceanographic data sets so that they are easily accessible by scientists and non-scientists. The application will focus on colocation with observations from Argo floats, which measure ocean properties globally as deep as 6000 meters below the surface. Examples of data that the application will be able to help visualize include: hurricane trajectories, winds, and precipitation; these data will be combined with ocean temperature and salinity observations from Argo profiles. Users will be able to view and download data without the need to install anything other than a web browser or to directly import data into their programming environment of choice. Argovis 2.0 is intended to be both a scientific research and educational tool. The investigators envision it being used for exhibits and for classroom learning activities in oceanic and atmospheric sciences.

This project will develop Argovis 2.0, a web application for collocating atmospheric and oceanic data with Argo profile data. The application will be able to collocate two or more observational datasets in latitude, longitude, depth, and time. Users will be able to view and download data using a web browser or by directly importing data into their programming environment of choice such as Matlab proprietary programming language or open source such as Python or R. Argovis 2.0 builds on Argovis 1.0, using a standard architecture comprising of a front-end, back-end, and database. The MongoDB database is used to store gridded and non-gridded data such as the point based and finely gridded datasets. The database outputs in JSON format and is accessed by an Express.js back end framework. The backend sends requests and responds by sending either HTML or JSON data to the user. Finally, Angular is the web application framework for the front end. User generated charts and maps are built using tiled mapping and charting libraries Leaflet and Plotly. The project will serve a broad community of scientists and professors who use atmospheric and oceanic science in their research and teaching, as well as the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Argovis is a system for rapidly searching, downloading and visualizing Earth system data, including oceanic measurements, satellite gridded products, weather events, and other synthesized products. The central goal for the Argovis development is to lower the barriers to consumption for this publicly available data, in order to increase its utilization by scientists and the public, and make it more available for use in rapidly evolving environments, like websites, interactive educational exercises, and research applications that study, for example, upper ocean changes during weather events. Examples of applications Argovis supports include demo Jupyter notebooks and educational activities created as part of this project and made available online; research studies conducted as part of this or other projects; the web application GANDALF (an aid to AUV pilots operating in the Gulf of Mexico, which also uses data from Argovis); and a case study for seamless retrieval of coincident data from ICESat-2 and Argo to enable improved targeted and exploratory studies across the cryosphere and open ocean realms (Bissom et al. 2023).

The central intellectual merit of the Argovis project is to enable and expedite seamless integration and exploration of diverse datasets - ranging from satellite products to oceanographic in-situ observations -  so scientists, educators, and the public can quickly access essential information for understanding our environment and planet, including exploring interactions between the ocean and the atmosphere.  Unlike conventional systems, Argovis's advanced search functionalities significantly reduce the time and effort traditionally required to select and download  the data of interest for research and education.  The careful indexing and rich search features provided by Argovis perform this labor quickly and automatically for data consumers (be they scientists, educators, or the public), so that data returned are highly focused on the question at hand and rote data cleaning procedures are greatly reduced. Furthermore, the mechanisms for performing those searches are kept consistent, simplifying comparisons and cross-referencing across different datasets.

In addition to powerful and targeted search capabilities for Earth system data, Argovis provides a platform for visualizing these data in easy-to-understand maps and charts via a web application, free to use and available to the public at argovis.colorado.edu. This platform allows the public to explore data about the Earth in a self-directed manner, and serves as a tool to enable educational activities that help students develop intuitive and quantitative understanding of the ocean.

Beyond the web-facing data service it provides, Argovis also demonstrates a reusable technology stack and engineering methodology that can be adopted by labs, universities and other data-generating organizations to rapidly duplicate Argovis' key benefits for other fields of research. All of Argovis' code and documentation are open-source and freely MIT licenced. Argovis' documentation also describes its operation and maintenance, so third parties can quickly set up similar open data services, if of interest.

Beyond the immediate technical impact of rapid analysis and cross-referencing on a project-by-project basis, the broader societal impact of data services like Argovis over time comes from maximizing the consumption and utility of publicly funded and available data. Data collection can be expensive; society gets the most for its investment when the data extracted from experiments and expeditions is used repeatedly, as broadly and transparently as possible by as diverse a base of consumers as possible. By standardizing what is often originally highly heterogeneous data and making that data accessible through a consistent search service, data services make what once may have been data specialized to one scientific field accessible to many more, enabling insights that can only come from cross-disciplinary collaboration and perspectives. These advantages accrue not only across scientific disciplines, but to other sectors of society, as educators, artists, news media, and the general public begin accessing and understanding data collected by the scientific community.

As part of this Argovis project, studies about oceanic processes and interactions between the atmosphere and the ocean have been conducted. As one example, Karnauskas and Giglio (2022) describe upwelling at equatorial islands. Upwelling fuels marine life by bringing nutrient-rich water into the sunlit surface layer. Upwelling can also impact the atmosphere, because the water brought to the surface is colder, which affects the wind and clouds. The surprising abundance and diversity of life (from corals to fish to seabirds) around equatorial islands are thought to be caused by a unique form of upwelling. Argo profiles measuring temperature, salinity, and pressure were queried from Argovis and used to reveal the structure of this unique form of upwelling. Unlike most upwelling zones (e.g., California), which are driven directly by the wind combined with Earth's rotation, upwelling at equatorial islands is shown here to be due to a massive underwater current that flows along the equator colliding with the islands. These insights have immediate implications for predictions of how such important tropical ecosystems will change in the future.
